November 8, 1992: Fiction
THE TALE OF THE BODY THIEF, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $24.) To prove he is still
a hero among the living dead, Lestat embarks on a dangerous enterprise; "The
Vampire Chronicles," continued.
THE STARS SHINE DOWN, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $23.) The fortunes of a
successful businesswoman are suddenly imperiled by secrets from her past and
present relationships.
DRIVING FORCE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $21.95.) An ex-jockey's horse-
transport business is besieged by a series of mysterious deaths.
MOSTLY HARMLESS, by Douglas Adams. (Harmony, $20.) The fifth volume of
the "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" series.
SABINE'S NOTEBOOK, by Nick Bantock. (Chronicle Books, $17.95.) Continuing
the epistolary romance begun in "Griffin & Sabine."
WAITING TO EXHALE, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $22.) The friendships and
romances of four black women in Phoenix.
THE SHADOW RISING, by Robert Jordan. (Tor/ Doherty, $24.95.) A fantasy tale.
THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law
student probes the murder of two Supreme Court justices.
GRIFFIN & SABINE, by Nick Bantock. (Chronicle Books, $17.95.) The romance of
an artist and a secret admirer, told through cards and letters.
THE SECRET HISTORY, by Donna Tartt. (Knopf, $23.) Close friends at a small
college must deal with the consequences of a crime they committed.
WHERE IS JOE MERCHANT? by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$19.95.) A couple on the trail of a dead rock star who has been sighted.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$14.95.) A photographer and a lonely farmer's wife in Iowa.
GERALD'S GAME, by Stephen King. (Viking, $23.50.) Twenty-eight hours of
horror suffered by a woman handcuffed to a bedpost.
MEXICO, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $25.) While researching the
lives of his ancestors, an American journalist learns about the history of the land
south of the border.
BEST DESTINY, by Diane Carey. (Pocket, $20.) A new "Star Trek" novel.
LEAVING COLD SASSY, by Olive Ann Burns. (Ticknor & Fields, $21.) The story
November 8, 1992
Non-Fiction
SEX, by Madonna. (Warner, $49.95.) Erotic photographs of the pop star by Steven
Meisel, and her reflections on them.
THE WAY THINGS OUGHT TO BE, by Rush H. Limbaugh 3d. (Pocket, $22.)
Anecdotes and opinions offered by the talk show host.
IT DOESN'T TAKE A HERO, by H. Norman Schwarzkopf with Peter Petre. (Linda
Grey/ Bantam, $25.) The autobiography of the general who commanded the allied
forces in the gulf war.
I CAN'T BELIEVE I SAID THAT! by Kathie Lee Gifford with Jim Jerome. (Pocket,
$22.) The autobiography of the co-host of the television show "Live With Regis
and Kathie Lee."
THE SILENT PASSAGE, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $16.) The
psychological and social significance of menopause for today's women.
EVERY LIVING THING, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Continuing the
memoirs of the Yorkshire veterinarian.
EARTH IN THE BALANCE, by Al Gore. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The author
discusses factors affecting the environment and what must be done to save the
earth.
THE TE OF PIGLET, by Benjamin Hoff. (Dutton, $16.) Aspects of Taoist
philosophy explained through the actions of an A. A. Milne character.
BANKRUPTCY 1995, by Harry E. Figgie Jr. with Gerald J. Swanson. (Little,
Brown, $19.95.) The authors predict the collapse of America under Government
debt and suggest ways to cope with it.
WOMEN WHO RUN WITH THE WOLVES, by Clarissa Pinkola Estes. (Ballantine,
$20.) A Jungian analyst reinterprets myths and folk tales to enable women to
understand their psyches.
TRUMAN, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A biography of the 33d
President.
THE SENATOR, by Richard E. Burke with William and Marilyn Hoffer. (St.
Martin's, $23.95.) The recollections of a man who served as an aide to Edward M.
Kennedy for 10 years.
GENIUS, by James Gleick. (Pantheon, $27.50.) The life and achievements of
Richard Feynman, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist.
YOUNG MEN & FIRE, by Norman Maclean. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) An
account of a disastrous fire in a Montana forest in 1949.
